newsitem.title: AUSTRALIA: Cricket-Stuart takes hat-trick to rout Pakistan.
newsitem.headline: Cricket-Stuart takes hat-trick to rout Pakistan.

text.p: Australia fast bowler Anthony Stuart claimed a hat-trick in a five-wicket haul as Pakistan struggled to 181 for nine in 50 overs in their limited overs World Series match on Thursday.
Stuart, playing in only his third one-day match for his country, dismissed Ijaz Ahmed, Mohammad Wasim and wicketkeeper Moin Khan in successive deliveries to rout Pakistan's top order.
The lanky New South Wales paceman became only the second Australian bowler -- and the 12th in the world -- to take a hat-trick in a limited overs international.
After staggering to 29 for five, the tourists were rescued by opener Inzamam-ul-Haq with a hard-hitting 64 and an equally belligerent 33 from captain and all-rounder Wasim Akram.
It was a spirited bowling performance by Australia after they failed to qualify for the final of the triangular tournament, their worst limited overs performance at home for 17 years.
In a devastating early burst, Stuart took the first five wickets to fall in the space of 14 deliveries from the southern end at a miserly cost of just one run.
In his sixth over with the new ball, Stuart lured Ijaz and Wasim to edge faint catches to wicketkeeper Ian Healy before Moin deflected a thicker edge to Australia captain Mark Taylor at first slip.
With the best-of-three final against West Indies starting in Sydney on Saturday, Inzamam made a timely return to form after being promoted up the order.
Inzamam smashed five fours on his way to half-century and his score amounted to more than half his side's total at the time of his dismissal in the 36th over.
Almost inevitably, given his superb figures of five for 26 in 10 overs, Stuart played a role in Inzamam's dismissal, taking a fine low catch on the boundary to remove the burly right-hander.
Fielding at deep mid-off, Stuart repeated the trick to catch all-rounder Shahid Afridi for 29 to complete an outstanding personal performance.
His hat-trick was the first by an Australian in a one-day international since fast bowler Bruce Reid in Sydney in January 1986.
